message: I'm curious about this too.
I'm less curious about who is doing it (though it does matter) and rather what issue they had/are having.
I know Jacob has Django on PyPy in production.  Fijal (bit of a special case, admittingly) is using it for telescopes or something in production :)
Why would one like to use PyPy over CPython? Is it faster? Easier to deploy?
speeeed is the main thing
Speed is the driving force behind using something like PyPy - but @gregmuellegger - what's hard about deployment with cpython?

@jessenoller cannot think of any :-) cpython is usually preinstalled in most server environments. Maybe there are situation where cpython is not available? ... hm yeah, jython. Running PyPy on Jython?
Ok just to clarify PyPy is a python implementation, written in python. So it means it needs a Python interpreter like CPython or Jython or IronPython first to be able to run PyPy, right?
Not exactly.
Yes it's written in Python, but more accurately "RPython" which is a subset of PYthon we can efficiently compile to C
(and other targets)
so you have a normal pypy binary like you would have a CPython one
Cool. Makes more sense now for me. Thanks
you also need a C compiler to build PyPy :D
You need a Python interpreter to build PyPy in the same way you need a C compiler to build CPython, doesn't mean you need it at runtime.
@alex heh, just read about object spaces in PyPy and saw lazy evaluation and tainted objects —this is great!
@alex That didn't help the analogy :-P
You don't *need* a C compiler (do you?).  You need a backend target.  But that could be Java, .net/CLI, or LLVM, rather than C, couldn't it?
Is it ready for prime time?
I thought they had a ways to go
Weeel, LLVM is unmaintained AFAIK, and JVM and CLI only work on a branch
We consider the JIT on 32 and 64 bit to be production ready.
For example, the PyPy translator (200k lines of Python) we run exclusively on top of PyPy because its so much faster
did someone delete a message here?
it confused me
yes
:) convore still showed one message here
would love to hear more about django on pypy in production - difficulty of setup and maintenance, memory footprint, and benefits/downsides.
setup should be about the same as CPython, presuming your using gunicorn
make a virtualenv using PyPy, install gunicorn; do your thing
memory footprint I would expect to be larger, and performance better (and when it's not, let us know!)
@alex Is your Postgres driver a part of PyPy now? Also I would assume sqlite is supported since thats just in the stdlib?
@coderanger sqlite is supported; there's a cx_Oracle port in pypy, my psycopg is still external
@alex Can I install it separately or would I have to install PyPy from your branch?
@coderanger unfortunately ATM RPython modules must be compiled with the pypy binary, and can't be loaded as shared objects
The future is bright. I look forward to the day PyPy is faster than both C and Java.

From the same people who brought you "running numerical code 50x faster" we bring you, running Tornado 2x faster: http://www.reddit.com/r/Python/comments/fr4w9/benchmarking_go_and_python_web_servers/c1i2of9
What is the hello in tornado/pypy doing in every request?  What happen when some kind of i/o is implied ?
Not sure I understand the question
ok
@alex what is the test doing in every request? a simple returning "hello world"? or anything more complex?
@jdaguilera take a look at the article, it contains the exact code
